intro: Tetrodea comosa, commonly known as the hairy tetrodea, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its leaves are pinnately divided, with a serrated edge, and it often grows in moist, shaded environments. Tetrodea comosa is valued in traditional medicine for its potential anti-inflammatory properties.
